title: The Future of Content Marketing
excerpt: Exploring how AI and new platforms are reshaping content creation and distribution.
content:
The landscape of content marketing is evolving rapidly. Artificial intelligence and emerging platforms are fundamentally changing how we create, distribute, and consume content.

AI tools are making content creation more accessible, allowing marketers to produce high-quality content at scale. However, this also means that authentic, human-created content becomes even more valuable.

New platforms continue to emerge, each with its own unique audience and content format. The key is understanding where your audience spends their time and creating content that fits naturally into those spaces.

The future belongs to marketers who can balance automation with authenticity, scale with personalization, and data with creativity.

title: Building a Content Engine That Scales
excerpt: Lessons learned from building content teams that drive real business results.
content:
Scaling a content operation isn't just about producing more content—it's about building systems that enable consistent, high-quality output.

Start with clear processes. Document your content creation workflow, from ideation to publication. This creates repeatability and allows team members to work independently.

Invest in the right tools. Content management systems, collaboration platforms, and analytics tools can dramatically increase your team's efficiency.

Build a content calendar that balances planned content with flexibility for timely topics. This ensures you're always publishing while staying relevant.

Most importantly, focus on quality over quantity. One exceptional piece of content will outperform ten mediocre ones every time.

title: Why Storytelling Matters in B2B
excerpt: Moving beyond features and benefits to connect with your audience on a deeper level.
content:
B2B marketing often defaults to features and benefits, but the most effective B2B content tells a story.

Stories create emotional connections. Even in B2B, decisions are made by people, and people are driven by emotion. A compelling story can make your product memorable in a way that feature lists never will.

Use customer success stories. Show how your product solved a real problem for a real company. These narratives are more persuasive than any sales pitch.

Tell the story of your company. Why does your company exist? What problem are you solving? This context helps prospects understand not just what you do, but why it matters.

Remember: people don't buy products, they buy solutions to problems. Stories help them see themselves using your solution.

title: The Content Marketing Playbook
excerpt: A practical guide to creating content that converts, from ideation to distribution.
content:
Effective content marketing requires a systematic approach. Here's a playbook that works:

**Ideation**: Start with your audience's pain points. What questions do they have? What challenges do they face? Use tools like Answer the Public or customer interviews to find topics.

**Creation**: Focus on depth over breadth. One comprehensive guide is more valuable than ten surface-level posts. Aim to be the definitive resource on your topic.

**Optimization**: Optimize for both search engines and humans. Use keywords naturally, structure content for readability, and include clear calls-to-action.

**Distribution**: Don't just publish and hope. Share across multiple channels—your website, social media, email newsletters, and relevant communities.

**Measurement**: Track what matters. Look beyond vanity metrics to engagement, leads generated, and revenue attributed to content.

title: Measuring What Matters in Content
excerpt: Beyond vanity metrics: how to track content that actually moves the needle.
content:
Page views and social shares feel good, but they don't tell you if your content is actually working.

Focus on engagement metrics: time on page, scroll depth, and comments show whether people are actually reading and interacting with your content.

Track conversion metrics: how many readers become leads? How many leads become customers? This connects content directly to business outcomes.

Measure content efficiency: how long does it take to create? What's the cost per lead? This helps you optimize your content investment.

Look at content attribution: which pieces drive the most qualified leads? Which support customers through the buying journey?

Remember: the goal isn't to create viral content. It's to create content that drives business results.

title: Content Distribution Strategies
excerpt: Creating great content is only half the battle. Here's how to get it seen.
content:
Great content that nobody sees is worthless. Distribution is just as important as creation.

**Owned channels**: Your website, blog, and email list are your most valuable distribution channels. Build these assets consistently.

**Social media**: Share content across relevant platforms, but adapt the format for each. What works on LinkedIn won't work on Twitter.

**Communities**: Find where your audience gathers—forums, Slack groups, Reddit communities. Share valuable content without being spammy.

**Partnerships**: Collaborate with other creators, companies, or influencers in your space. Guest posts and co-created content expand your reach.

**Repurposing**: Turn one piece of content into multiple formats—blog post becomes a video, becomes a podcast, becomes a Twitter thread.

The best distribution strategy is one that reaches your specific audience where they already spend time.

title: Why Marketing Leaders Aren't Hiring
excerpt: They no longer see the marketing org as 'roles', but as tasks that need to get done.
content: Marketing leaders aren't hiring for one simple reason: They no longer see the marketing org as “roles” but as tasks that need to get done. A CMO used to default to: hire in-house for core work, maybe hire an agency for campaigns. But budget constraints and AI have shaken that model. Now each task has multiple competing paths to execution: - In-house hire → high control, long ramp, high fixed cost - Agency → expertise, speed, external perspective, higher per-task cost - Freelancer → flexible, narrow skill coverage, variable quality - AI workflow → cheap, instant, scalable, but unreliable and requires oversight The difficulty for marketing leaders is that the time horizon is short: they need results this quarter, and switching costs are high if they misallocate. So GTM strategy becomes an allocation game: Which tasks are core differentiators → keep in-house Which are high-stakes but episodic → outsource to agency Which are specialized but limited → hire freelancers Which are repeatable but non-differentiating → automate with AI workflows The job of a marketing leader today is less about building a perfect team structure and more about being a portfolio manager to execute on their vision. The most savvy leaders aren’t asking, “Do I need another hire?” They’re asking, “For this specific task, what’s the right execution path given cost, speed, quality, and time-horizon?” But I've never been a CMO, so maybe I'm way off.
